comments.text:
Does God Exist?
 
To study this question we will divide existence into two sets. Theistic 
things and NonTheistic things are the two sets. We all agree that 
NonTheistic things do exist. Sun, moon, carrots, etc. In dispute is whether 
there is anything in the set called Theistic… or is the Theistic set 
actually a null set?
 
Argument: NonTheistic things exist. If NonTheistic things cannot exist 
without Theistic things, then Theistic things must exist.  If the premises 
are true, then the conclusion must be valid. 
 
The first premise is true:.NonTheistic things do exist. Sun, moon, carrots 
and people are NonTheistic. This is not in debate.
 
The second premise is NonTheistic things cannot exist without Theistic 
things. Please consider the following arguments as proof that NonTheistic 
things cannot exist without Theistic things.
 
Nontheistic things either 1) Had a beginning or 2) have existed for an 
infinite period of time. There are no other possibilities. It is obvious 
that either 1 or 2 is true . But the following arguments will prove that 
NEITHER can be true without the existence of Theistic things.
 
1. NONTHEISTIC THINGS HAD A BEGINNING: If theistic things is a null set, 
then everything is nontheistic, and NOTHING turned into EVERYTHING. This is 
impossible. 


2. NONTHEISTIC THINGS HAVE EXISTED FOR AN INFINITE TIME: If nontheistic 
things have existed for an infinite period of time, then the sun and stars 
would have burned up by now (referring to 2nd Law of Thermodynamics). If 
theistic things is a null set, then everything is nontheistic and nothing 
exists outside of the nontheistic set. The nontheistic set would succumb to 
"heat death" since it cannot perpetuate life sustaining temperatures and 
there is nothing outside of the nontheistic set to act upon it to 
perpetuate life sustaining temperatures. 
 
So, it is  impossible for NonTheistic things to have had a beginning 
without the existence of Theistic things. It is also impossible for 
NonTheistic things to have existed infinitely without the existence of 
Theistic things. 
 
So, whether  NonTheistic things had a beginning or not, neither case can 
have occurred without Theistic things.
 
Summary: If NTH exists. And if NTH cannot exist without TH. Then TH must 
exist. 

IOW: If NonTheistic Things exist, and if NonTheistic Things cannot exist 
without Theistic Things, then Theistic Things must exist.﻿

comments.text:
+FireLight The obvious fallacy comes in your "Myra is a cat" example. You 
seem to think that the following argument is invalid:

Myra is a Cat
All Cats are Moons
Therefore Myra is a Moon

The problem, which you're failing to see, is that it actually IS a 
logically valid argument. You are conflating validity with soundness.

Validity within logic comes from whether the conclusion follows the 
premises, not whether the premises are true in real life. The conclusion 
that Myra is a Moon is logically valid, and to say that Myra is not a moon 
would be a logical falsehood.

However, the argument is not *sound* because the second premise, as we 
define it in real life, is not true. We can check the truth of our 
definitions by comparing them against evidence. We classify moons and cats 
as different things, but even in real life it could be argued that by 
launching poor Myra into high Earth orbit she could become a moon.

This is how +NonStampCollector demonstrated that you can plug in anything 
into your "theistic things" slot and still come up with an equally valid 
logical conclusion. Moreover, polytheism and monotheism are mutually 
exclusive sets: if one is true, the other, by definition, is false. 
Monotheism is the belief that there is only one god. If you find out there 
is more than one god, *by definition* you cannot be a monotheist, even if 
you only put your trust in one of the gods.

Of course, this would be a lot easier if you 1) defined "theistic things" 
and 2) provided testable evidence of said things.

comments.text:
+NonStampCollector Variables in valid arguments are not flexible. In other 
words, one can not disprove the validity of an argument by substituting a 
different variable,:


To illustrate, the following is an accepted valid argument:


Myra is a Cat
All Cats are Animals
Therefore, Myra is an Animal


If the premises are true in a valid argument, then the conclusion must be 
true. The premises are true and therefore the conclusion is true.


Now I will substitute Moon for Animal:


Myra is a Cat
All Cats are Moons
Therefore Myra is an Moon


If the premises are true in a valid argument, then the conclusion must be 
true. The 2nd premise is not true and therefore the conclusion is not 
valid. 



Substituting PolyTheistic for Theistic in my argument, does not invalidate 
my argument. 


To show my argument to be invalid, you must either show that my conclusion 
does not follow from the premises or show that one of my premises are 
untrue.


The argument still stands. The existence of Theistic Things has been proved.

collecting in scar tissue...

comments.text:
Is there Really a Supernatural Dimension?

Deists believe that a supernatural power created the Universe. But where is 
the proof? And who’s favorite supernatural power was responsible? How about 
Thor, Allah, Brahma or the Christian God? How is the existence of 
Supernatural beings proved in the first place?  

Let’s assume that there are no Supernatural beings. Are they really 
necessary for the universe to exist?

We’ll divide POSSIBLE EXISTENCE into the Non Supernatual Universe (NSU) and 
the Supernatual Universe (SU). The Supernatual Universe (SU) represents 
everything supernatural… any deities whether real or imagined. This 
includes Thor, Allah, Brahma, the Christian God, etc .  The Non Supernatual 
Universe (NSU) is everything else. We are assuming that SU is empty, a null 
set.

Let’s consider what we absolutely know about the Universe:The Universe 
exists. Either 1) the NSU has always existed or 2) the NSU had a beginning. 
There are no other possibilities. 

This statement is true by logic alone. It’s like saying that if something 
doesn’t have an end, it will last forever… only stating it in reverse.

(1) runs into a problem with the Second Law of Thermodynamics, (Entropy): 
If NSU “has always been here” then it has existed for an INFINITE period of 
time. The stars would have burned out after an INFINITE period. The earth 
would have stopped rotating, etc, etc. (Energy with sufficient utility to 
burn as a star would no longer exist after an INFINITE period.) As energy 
is used, it loses its ability to do work. To verify, Google "An isolated 
system's ability to do work decreases over time" If SU is a null set, then 
NSU is an isolated system… a closed system. If NSU is a closed or isolated 
system, the energy in NSU should have lost its ability to do work after an 
INFINITE period of time. 

(2) raises a question. If NSU had a beginning and if SU is the null set, 
then there was “nothing” before NSU had its beginning. For (2) to be 
possible, then “nothing” must turn into “everything”. If we are to take 
science seriously, we cannot accept that “nothing” can “POOF” turn into the 
“everything”. After all, what can “nothing” do except nothing, since there 
is nothing in “nothing” to “do” anything?

So, if SU is empty, neither 1 nor 2 is consistent with science. That would 
mean that all possibilities for the existence of the NSU are not very 
believable without SU. Without a Supernatural Universe, we are faced with a 
choice: either nothing turned into everything or we must throw the 2nd Law 
of Thermodynamics under the bus. Hmm... Will the true creator please stand 
up? I hope it’s not Thor!

But what if there is some unknown nonsupernatual something … that created 
the NSU? The problem is… we must include that something in the definition 
of NSU. Something can’t cause its self to come into existence. 
Additionally, there can be no “unsupernatual something” that is outside of 
the closed system of the NSU to inject energy into the NSU to make (1) 
possible. NSU, by definition includes all unsupernatual things. 

One might say "How did the SU (Supernatural Universe) come into existence 
or last forever?" The "Super" in Supernatural means above the natural or 
greater than the natural... not subject to the laws that govern the 
natural. This is the heart of the issue. The deist argues "Since the 
existence of the universe doesn’t make sense without the supernatual, there 
must be a Supernatural explanation". 

So, it appears that there must be something Supernatural to explain what we 
know about the Non Supernatural Universe… to explain how it has existed 
forever, or how it had a beginning.

But, support for the existence of any particular deity has not been shown 
here… not for Thor, Allah, Brahma, the Christian God, etc. It indicates 
that some supernatural power does exist…

But who?﻿

comments.text:
+Hasnain Mohammed I do not deny the existence of a creator. Only *testable 
proof* of a creator. There's nothing in nature that can't be done *without* 
a creator deity. Sure, there's things we don't understand yet. Doesn't mean 
goddidit. 

You say "experimental sciences demonstrate that the elements and natural 
factors cannot exert any independent influence". That's airy-fairy 
nonsense. First of all: independent influence on *what*? The sun warms the 
earth. That's a natural factor exerting an independent influence. When I 
toss a ball into the air it falls back. That's a natural factor exerting an 
independent influence. Or, more precisely, a *dependent* influence. Nature, 
as we know it here on Earth (and in the Universe at large) is a series of 
dependencies. They've been loosely termed "The Laws of Nature".

You say "...and our rational deductions point to the conclusion that 
nothing occurs in nature without a reason..." Nature does not "reason". 
Nature is, as I said earlier, the result of physical, chemical and 
biological process. It has no goal or purpose and therefore cannot have a 
"reason".

You say "a considerable number of scientists have a religious outlook...". 
How many is a "considerable number", and so what? Brown University's 
Professor Ken Miller is a practicing Catholic. He was also the plaintiffs' 
star witness in Kitzmiller v Dover, a landmark case in the Separation of 
Church and State battle. He literally made mincemeat of the Intelligent 
Design argument. What are your sources for the "considerable number"? Wait; 
I have some numbers:

                               1914        1933   1998
Personal belief            27.7%    15%     7.0%
Personal disbelief        52.7%     68%  72.2%
Doubt or agnosticism   20.9%    17%   20.8%
*Edward J. Larson and Larry Witham: "Leading Scientists Still Reject God." 
Nature, 1998; 394, 313*

And this is an old study. The numbers have almost certainly changed for the 
better (our better, that is).

The biggest problem I have with any Creator Deity is *why*? Why would any 
god create this vast universe, most of which is implacably hostile, just 
for little us?

We don't need god(s). Science works.
comments.author: Mike Regan

comments.text:
+Clyde Rembrandt  I did not say that atheists believe that everything is a 
cosmic accident. The universe we see is the result of physical, chemical 
and biological processes; some of which are well understood, some less so, 
others almost not at all. They are *clearly not accidental*. While our 
understanding of the universe is certainly incomplete, it *is* growing... 
daily. We will probably never have a *perfect* understanding of the 
universe but the need for a creator deity becomes smaller as our 
understanding increases. Our lack of understanding, however, does not, in 
any way, imply a Creator. It just means we don't know... yet.

I also didn't suggest that Atheist beliefs are (or should be) examined in 
science classes. If you read it that way you did so through Ken Ham's 
"God-Glasses".

 If a belief in a Supreme Creator gives you comfort, you're welcome to it. 
Just don't teach your superstitions in our *Science* classrooms to *MY* 
children.

comments.text:
+5179anonymous Anti-natalism? I don't want parenthood banned entirely 
because I don't want to see the end of the human race. I can see the logic 
of China's one child policy but I still think that's a bridge too far 
because I think there may be some benefits to growing up with siblings (not 
that I've experienced this for myself).

Perhaps a two child policy would be a good idea. Or if you need stable 
finances to apply for a loan, why the same before having kids? I find it 
surprising that in the abortion debate the pro-abortion side call 
themselves pro-choice. In a different world the anti abortion side would be 
called pro-choice and instead of debating whether or not abortion should be 
banned the two sides would be debating whether or not abortion should be 
mandatory for people who already have too many kids or people on welfare 
(not that I want to condemn people on welfare too much, seeing as how I'm 
on welfare but then again I'm not a serial parent and I know that 
successful parents tend to raise successful kids. I don't want to condone 
welfare recipients even if I am one).

I think it's great that the childhood survival rate has improved in Uganda 
but I think they could get an even higher percentage if there were just 
less children there in the first place. It just seems to me paradoxical 
that their solution to the problem of high childhood mortality is also the 
cause of high childhood mortality. Also I don't think having more children 
than adults makes for a stable society.

The vast majority of 25 year olds shouldn't have kids? Well? At 26 I don't 
think I'd know how to raise kids and I have no intention of trying at any 
stage of my life (though in my case it's for less noble reasons than you, I 
just don't want to face the work, stress and expense of raising kids) but 
if I think of my mother, being 21 years older than me, she didn't know how 
to raise kids. She learned quickly. There are first-time parents at 40 who 
don't know how to raise kids. I think instead of debating whether they 
should be parents at 20 or 40, my way of thinking is that first-time 
parents of any age much learn on the job. The only way your thirtyager 
friends could learn parenting skills is by being parents.

It's true that 40 year olds are likely to have more money than 20 year olds 
and I don't want to see children grow up in poverty. But I also don't like 
to see children grow up with absent parents. While I fully support having 
women in the work place, a necessary consequence of this is that kids get 
less parenting. This could apply for twentyager parents or fortyager 
parents. 20 year olds will work towards success but once they succeed they 
as 40 year olds must work to maintain it. Duel income families earn a lot 
more but are they still in the black if you account for the expense of 
daycare? Depends on the job I guess.
comments.author: Luke Beauchamp

comments.text:
+Luke Beauchamp well if you walk too far down that road (is it alright to 
sentence people you don't know to suffering just to satisfy your own whims) 
then you become an anti-natalist and believe that nobody should have 
children at all. Which I kind of agree with. Though most would see it as an 
extreme position. This is part of the reason I don't want to have my own 
children. Why should I condemn some hypothetical person, without ever 
consulting him/her, to the pain of adolescence, puberty, the daily grind, 
and finally old age.. just so that I could satisfy some narcissistic 
curiosity about what it would be like to have a little copy of myself 
running around, or so that I could have someone to call me when I'm old and 
infirm? Seems selfish.

(One of) the problem(s) in developing countries like Uganda is that 
traditionally families would need to have 12 kids just to ensure the 
survival of the species, because upwards of 80-90% would not make it to 
reproductive age. Now as standards of living improve (access to clean 
water, healthcare, medicine, food, etc etc), the death rate drops 
precipitously, but the birth rate lags behind. Eventually, in developed 
countries, birth rates also tend to fall very low. Until you get to a point 
where the population is actually in decline (look at Japan or Germany, or 
even the USA if you discount the effect of immigration). But it takes five 
or more generations for cultural norms to adjust, and in the interim we 
have dangerously exploding population figures. The light at the end of the 
tunnel is that some demographers think world population will peak at about 
10-15 billion.. and then eventually start to decline all over the world. 
That's assuming standards of living can be maintained.

I know my wait-until-40-to-have-kids thing is also kind of out there. I 
just personally feel that the reason most people think 12 year olds should 
not be having kids (they are too immature) also applies to the vast 
majority of 25 year olds. I'm currently 35 and still feel as though most of 
my friends are not yet mature enough to really handle raising a child.
comments.author: 5179anonymous

with their kids. My (sinlge) Mum were in her 20s and we'd go on long bike 
rides, play soccer in the back yard, stuff like that. I think there could 
be benefits to having parents that are young enough to be psychically fit. 
True she gave up having a career except that was never the least bit career 
minded to begin with.

And Uganda? Sure they could do with "less fertility" but I think the 
Ugandans should still take a bit of responsibility. They should use 
contraceptives.

I saw this other video of Stephan Fry vs the evil Ann Widdecombe. Stephen 
Fry says it's bad that the Catholics make Africans think contraceptives are 
a sin (agreed) but evil Ann Widdecombe says she was a missionary in Africa 
and then she says it's a good thing they each have ten kids even though it 
leads to a modest amount of food being divided among more kids because she 
says there's no old age pension there so the parents need to have enough 
kids to ensure that one or two of them survive so they get supported in 
their old age. Except that their high rate of childhood mortality is caused 
by malnutrition. What kind of stupid Christian circular logic is that? They 
have limited food resources and too many kids so their all starving and Ann 
Widdecombe thinks the solution to this problem is for them to have even 
more kids? I want to kick her in her ugly face.

And for the African parents? Do they think it's OK to have ten kids and 
have eight of them starve to death and two of them starve and barely 
survive until adulthood just so they can have a more comfortable 
retirement? Is it right to inflict horrible suffering on ten people just so 
two people can have a more pleasant retirement? It would be better for two 
parents to die at 50 (from lack of retirement plan) than for eight kids to 
die at 5. I find it hard to believe that any parents could be so selfish as 
to value their own happiness above their kids'. What kind of awful parents 
would make their kids suffer so they can live in greater comfort? Sounds 
like an Ann Widdecombe idea. Her politics are also based on the needs of 
the few outweighing the needs of the many.
